subject: RE: [Read_Alphabet] Re: FW: Hello All,
msgSnippet: [snip] I guess the present system is like that:  Cursive is quite a bit different visually from print fonts.  I personally can see that it would take a bit of
messageBody:
[snip]

 

I guess the present system is like that:  Cursive is quite a bit

different visually from print fonts.  I personally can see that it

would take a bit of effort (fun though it be) to learn how to read and

write QS, and I would be hesitant to have to learn a new way to type!

 

Once you are familiar with the letters and the sounds they represent, it doesn’t take that long to become used to a new key mapping – just some regular practice.  There is not a standard mapping at this point, and there has been discussion about the best way to accomplish this given the number of keys on a keyboard.  This is an area that still needs to be improved upon to hit upon a system that works well.  At this time, since most people learning QS know TO, using two key strokes which are transformed by the program keyman to map the output to the appropriate QS letter seems to work well.  But this is an interim solution that doesn’t really address building up one’s typing speed.

 

hAv fan ælDxniN /kwikskript.

 

Paige
